story: The Duchess of Sussex was snapped by her husband as she stood among giant redwoods in a New Zealand forest.The -year-old mum-to-be posed for the photograph in the Redwoods Forest in Rotorua on the final day of the couple’s first overseas tour as husband and we.The sweet snap was shared by Kensington Palace via the official Instagram account and was accompanied by a message from the newlyweds.The post read: “A message from The Duke and Duchess of Sussex: ‘Thank you New Zealand for the most wonderful last week of our tour.“It has been a privilege to meet so many friendly Kiwis.“Australia, Fiji, Tonga and NZ - we leave feeling inspired and reminded of how every single one of us can make a dference.”The post was also accompanied by a quote by Kate Sheppard, which read: “The rain that refreshes the parched ground, is made up of single drops.”The Duke of Sussex is given the photo credit on the Instagram post, meaning he was behind the camera capturing the moment.The stunning image followed an earlier post by Kensington Palace showing the royal couple walking hand-in-hand amongst the -year-old redwoods.The couple were seen exploring the majestic forest and its suspension bridges as their -day tour of Down Under came to a close.The Duke and Duchess are set to welcome their first child Spring , with news of Baby Sussex being announced as the couple touched down in Australia in mid-October.Kensington Palace said the couple, who married in Windsor in May, were delighted to be able to share this happy news with the public.The new royal baby will be seventh in line to the throne.

title: ww1 veterans the last tommies bbc four interviews
story: Survivors of the First World War will tell their personal tales of battles and bravery ahead of the centenary celebrations of the armistice agreement which ended the war on  November .One of the veterans recalled: You could feel the machine gun bullets flying past you - you had to keep on going.And another, Tommy Gay, told his story of the Battle of the Somme, in which , British troops were lost in a single day.Gay was just  at the time of the battle because he lied about his age to be conscripted.He said: I was one of the first to go up over the top - we met a hurricane of bullets.Some of the chaps were lying around with their arms off in pain.You couldnt help the poor souls... You couldnt help them at all.Another soldier remembered: We were able to see the infantry going forwards.In some cases they didnt get very far - they were just wiped out.The incredible accounts will be broadcast as part of a new BBC Four series titled WWI: The Last Tommies.And although the last surviving Tommy - Harry Patch - died nine years ago at the age of , the new programme contains never-before-seen interviews with Tommies recorded over the last  years while World War One was still within living memory.The amazing interviews are accompanied by digitally restored archive footage shot on the fronts and at home during the First World War.The first episode covers the early years of the war, in which the Pals Battalions went off to the front for the first time, while the second hears tells of the Somme.The third and final episode covers the Battle of Passchendaele in  - a battle fought in a quagmire of mud at a terrible cost to soldiers lives.It also discusses the unimaginable emotional tragedy of the war at home in Britain as the nation came to terms with the horror of the war.The series WWI: The Last Tommies will be broadcast on pm - pm Monday  November to Wednesday  November on BBC Four.

title: kiana smith purple birthmark covers face surgery
story: Kiana Smith, , was born with a port-wine stain birthmark on the left side of her face.The purple pigmentation also covered her neck and chest and left her the victim of cruel taunts during her school years.But Kiana, from Cumana in Trinidad, has undergone five surgeries and specialised laser treatment to help lessen then mark and is now an ambassador for the Vascular Birthmark Foundation.She has recently flown to New York for more treatment, but is concerned she can feel the mark growing back.I’m feeling some bulkiness along here with my chin and underneath a little bit, she told Barcroft TV.“The surgeries on my birthmark have helped so much. I don’t have this bulk on my face anymore.“As I would describe it, it’s like having this huge one-inch steak, the weight of it hanging on your face.“Sometimes I would feel the blood just running and pumping in my birthmark.“But I don’t have that anymore. I am able to speak much better which is fantastic. “A port-wine stain birthmark are called so because they look like someone has spilt port-wine on the skin.About  out of every , children are born with these marks.They most often occur on faces, heads, arms or legs and are caused by abnormal development of blood vessels in the skin.Unlike other birthmarks port-wine stains do not fade as a child gets older, instead it grows with them and often becomes hardened on the outside with age.But Kiana also have a genetic condition that causes her birthmark to overgrow.At one point it was so large she found it dficult to eat and drink.It is something that will always be there, always growing.“The birthmark will never go away. I have accepted that now.“I don’t want my whole le focused on the fact that I have a birthmark.“I don’t want it to keep me back from enjoying le.”Despite finally learning to accept the way she looks, Kiana said she will never get used to strangers staring at her.“People always stare at me when I leave the house,” she added.“I also feel like I have been in dficult situations with children.“You know children will often freak out, screaming, crying and everything and I have felt so bad because I’m the cause of their reaction.“I think entering high school was when I really had those first confidence issues“I would get called, ‘prune face’, ‘purple face’ and one of the popular ones was the ‘purple people eater’.“But my mother really helped me deal with this by treating me just as any other child.”Mum Ann McCarthy, , added: “I don’t think it affects her as much now as an adult as it did when she was much younger.“She’s able to be in society as a human being and like a normal human being.“I’ve always tried to emphasise to her, it is what is inside you that matters – not your external appearance.“I am unable to really say in words how proud I am of her.”But Kiana said all of the name-calling she faced earlier in le has only made her more determined to succeed.“I don’t really know what the future holds,” she said.“In terms of my birthmark, I’d like to have more laser surgery because that is critical.“I’m not going to say that I’ll ever be perfectly happy with my birthmark, because I don’t love it.“Despite everything, I am proud of myself and what I have achieved.”

title: newlywed woman doctor groin maggot inside her
story: The -year-old finally sought medical help after developing a red blister-like mark on her inner leg around two months after her honeymoon in Belize.The unnamed woman, from Tampa, Florida, was given antibiotics after visiting her GP but failed to see any improvements in her condition.She then decided to go to Tampa General Hospital, where the mark left doctors dumbfounded.Some speculated that the mark may have been a cyst while others contemplated it being an ingrown hair.Still unsatisfied with their answers, she decided to visit the Tampa’s Memorial Hospital where the horric truth finally wriggled out.Dr Enrico Camporesi noticed the skin around the sore had become hard, and decided to investigatethere may be an egg or bean beneath the surface.It was only after he consulted with a surgeon that the pair discovered the mark was in fact a live creature.The unnamed woman was immediately given local anaesthetic and surgeons got to work removing what turned out to be a maggot, known as a human botfly larva.The woman’s sore healed within a week and she was finally relieved of her constant groin itch.Her weird case has also been listed in the Journal of Investigative Medicine High Impact Case Reports.According to the medical journal’s authors, people who have been infected with the same type of maggot will often feel the creature wriggling around under the skin when they shower or attempt to cover the wound up.If left untreated, the adult larva will usually fall out of the skin within six weeks of infection, before maturing into an adult botfly.While the tiny creature is rare in the United States, it is extremely common in the Tropics.The botfly larva can easily be killed by taking away its air supply by putting Vaseline or similar on the skin where the lump is.But the larva will still need to be extracted from the human body.Adult botflies have non-al mouth parts and do not feed.

title: brand new house wales wonky brickwork sinking garden
story: When Darren Harris collected the keys to his freshly constructed £, four-bedroom house, he was shocked to find more than  defects.The -year-old was also stunned to learn the bumpy brickwork on his house wall had became a laughing stock of the neighbourhood.The civil engineer has shared pictures of the poor workmanship and plans to take legal action against Persimmon Homes, which built the house on the Martello Park estate in Pembroke, West Wales.Harris said: We got the keys to our house and I drove down to the property with my we.The neighbours came over and asked meI had seen the brickwork on the back of the house.They said to me We have been having a bit of a laugh and a giggle. It looks unstable, the brickwork is wavy and looks unsafe.He and his we, an area manager for Greggs bakery, then decided to take a look inside their property, but struggled to open the door.The engineer said: We put the key in but the door wouldnt budge. We couldnt get in.I thought there must be a problem and went back to the site office. A Persimmon agent came back with me and in the end he had to shoulder-barge the door to get it open.They discovered later that the door frame was fitted incorrectly.As time went on the list of problems expanded with Harris finding that drain covers werent fitted properly, paving was laid on top of rubble, the guttering doesnt reach the end of the house and water cascades down the sides when it rains.The doors inside all had to be rehung and Ive done so much work myself just to get it liveable.Everything is appallingly built - the workmanship is just shoddy. The problems are unbelievable.Mr Harris bought the house before it was built, after seeing a show home on the site.He said: It looked like a nice spot, with views of Pembroke Castle. We put a deposit down in February and planned to rent it out.But ever since we got the keys, the reality has been far from perfect.Its caused my we and I no end of worry and stress. She has been in tears. If my marriage wasnt so strong this could have finished us.Now Harris, from Sutton Coldfield in the Midlands, says he has no option but to take Persimmon Homes to court.He said: I have been on to head office. I have been brave enough to take them on and take them to the small claims court.The rectication work they attempted was not acceptable. I have given them the opportunity to put it right.I have had to put off getting my tenants in, which has resulted in losses of £,.We have been forced to get on with the retrospective work ourselves and it has cost us thousands. Thats the only way I could get the house finished and ready for our tenants.A spokesman for Persimmon Homes West Wales said: We are aware of Mr Harris’s concerns and we are working to reach a satisfactory conclusion.We have many happy customers across South Wales and we take customer service seriously.In October, Persimmon’s boss Jeff Fairburn walked off in the middle of a BBC interview after he was grilled about his whopping £million bonus.When questioned over any regrets about last year’s payout - cut from £million after a public outcry - Fairburn replied: “I’d rather not talk about that”.The payout is believed to be the largest by a listed UK firm, the BBC said.

title: britains strictest school bans girl 13 from wearing a poppy claiming its 1cm too big
story: Controversial Great Yarmouth Charter Academy - which last month called in ‘unorm police’ to measure girls’ skirt hems - told -year-old Courtney Dougal to take off the knitted tribute.School bosses said the symbol was “too large” - despite being just cm bigger than the traditional paper poppy.Courtney, in Year  at the Norfolk high school, had worn the poppy with pride on Tuesday only to be told by principal Barry Smith to remove it.Her dad Raymond Dougal, , said he was “absolutely disgusted” by the school’s tough stance.He said: “I am absolutely disgusted that they have made her take the poppy off. It is a little bit on the larger side but that is what makes it.“If it was huge and looked ridiculous I would not have sent her in it.“As it is it looks lovely. She is only little so that probably makes it look bigger than it is.He added: “I said to Courtney to just go in and wear it but she didn’t dare.”Mr Dougal bought the poppy in his local pub The Sportsmans Arms in Great Yarmouth, with contributions going to the Royal British Legion.Landlord John Vale said the school “overstepped the mark” this time, branding the ban “disrespectful.” Charter Academy defended the move.A statement said: “Poppies are available in school and we encourage pupils and staff to wear them unfortunately in this case we felt that the large knitted poppy was not appropriate to wear in school.“We are keen that pupils recognise and respect the sacrices made in war, and pupils are being encouraged to learn the poem In Flanders Field. Many will be taking part in the town’s Remembrance Day service on November .“We are also refurbishing and relocating plaques commemorating former pupils of the Great Yarmouth Grammar School that served in battle, as a permanent reminder of that important heritage.”Last month, furious parents hit out after the school called in unorm police to measure theof girls’ skirts.Experts from a nearby unorm shop were consulted after pupils started turning up in short skirts.The academy has previously been criticised for its strict new rules on unorm and haircuts — banning one style called Meet Me at McDonald’s.The curly-on-top, short-at-the-sides look has been compared to the eighties New Romantic movement.It features shaved sides and a long tousled top with a floppy fringe.

title: paraplegic athlete justin levene luton airport left behind wheelchair
story: Justin Levene’s self-propelled wheelchair was left behind on a flight, leaving the fiercely independent man stranded at the terminal, reports the BBC.To make matters worse, airport staff – oblivious to the fact that sporty Levene has done everything from play wheelchair basketball to cross the Alps and the Dolomites – offered to push him on a high-backed wheelchair.When he asked to be given a motorised buggy instead, Luton said it did not have one.Levene told the BBC: “I’ve worked very hard for a number of years to try and maintain all of my independence, and to be in one of the chairs they were offering would make me feel humiliated and degraded.“They insisted in trying to strap me down in it.“I wouldn’t have been able to adjust myself, and would have been at risk of getting a pressure sore.”He said that the situation left him with just one choice, to drag himself along the terminal floor for hundreds of yards towards the exit.A metal baggage trolley nearby was used as an uncomfortable-looking alternative mode of transport, with Levene hauling himself onto it, then pushing himself along the floor the rest of the way by using his hands.Criticising Luton – which was this year named the worst airport in the UK for the third year in a row in a passenger satisfaction survey – he said that “no matter how small” the airport hes flown from, there has “always” been a self-propelled wheelchair or buggy.The athlete is now suing the airport, as he says it failed to provide staff with disability equality and awareness training to an appropriate level for passengers when they require mobility help.In a statement Luton Airport told the BBC: “On discovering that Mr Levene’s flight had arrived without his wheelchair, our teams worked hard to find a solution, offering Mr Levene an assisted wheelchair as a temporary replacement.“Mr Levene declined all offers of help as he deemed them unacceptable.“While we apologiseMr Levene was dissatisfied with the service he received, we are satisfied that our agents and staff did all they could in dficult circumstances.”However, Levene, who also trains and mentors wheelchair athletes, told the BBC that he felt “humiliated” and “angry” that Luton’s staff failed to show any empathy.He said that no-one should be “forced to crawl through the airport or drag themselves along the floor”.According to a Justgiving fundraising page Levene set up to support spinal cord injury charity Aspire, two days before his st birthday, in June , he “coughed and suffered a herniated disc with severe nerve damage.“After almost four years having ious surgical procedures and undergoing spinal fusion, I am left in a wheelchair.“I was extremely active before this happened, with experience in martial arts and rugby, and whilst I will never give up hope on regaining full use of my legs, my le has been irreversibly changed, though my passion for sport continues.”Among his y list of sporting achievements, Levene played in the first ision of the national wheelchair basketball league, and in  borrowed a racing wheelchair to compete in the London Marathon.Last year he crossed the Alps and the Dolomites in Italy in the epic Rad Race, which involved going km “across some of the toughest climbs”, says Levene’s Instagram account.

title: colombian orphan tricked world he was saudi prince
story: His Royal Highness Khalid bin al-Saud was looking for a new home on Fisher Island off Miami, whose residents have included Oprah Winfrey and Julia Roberts.“This is my palace!” he exclaimed to the owner, scanning the sprawling space. “I will have million transferred to you by morning.”The money never materialised — and his new digs are rather less grand.These days the -year-old high roller is banged up in Miami’s Federal Detention Center, awaiting trial on charges including fraud, impersonating a foreign official and identity theft.His real name is Anthony Enrique Gignac. Far from being born into royalty he grew up as an orphan in Colombia.He had managed to make his way into the highest echelons of the global elite after befriending a well-connected asset manager from Orsett in Essex.Carl Marden Williamson, who had moved to the US in his s, was an ideal accomplice — being, according to a former colleague, “a master global networker”.It was urbane, charming Williamson who helped Gignac buy fake diplomatic licence plates from eBay — and who assured Florida’s elite that he had known the prince and his family for  years.Gignac’s aim in Florida was to rake in cash for what he promised would be hugely lucrative shares in Saudi oil giant Aramco, which was worth more than £.trillion.And he looked the part. He was accompanied everywhere by ‘bodyguards’ — handsome men wearing fake diplomatic badges and toting fake guns.A friend said: “Every single building you’d drive by he’d say, ‘Oh, my father owns that’.“He’d just spend, spend, spend, dumping out cash from Louis Vuitton duffle bags and tipping hundred-dollar bills to everyone: building managers, employees, handymen.”The fake prince’s Instagram account features photos of his private jet and yacht, wads of cash, Rolex watches and a dazzling diamond ring.Even tiny Foxy travelled around in a £, Louis Vuitton dog carrier.Gignac’s obsession with wealth is no doubt linked to his troubled childhood.He was one of the orphaned “throwaway” children on the mean streets of Colombia’s capital Bogota, and claims he had to look after his little brother by any means necessary.In a court statement he once revealed: “I was raped when I was five years old and sold on the streets to have sex with men to feed my brother. You don’t know the pain I’ve gone through.”But he was plucked from the crime-ridden city in , when a middle-class American couple adopted Anthony and his brother and moved them to Michigan.An exceptionally bright pupil, Gignac would lie to school friends that his parents were vastly wealthy.Aged , he ran away from home and assumed the identity of Saudi billionaire Prince Adnan Khashoggi.Soon he switched to a new target, Prince Khalid bin al-Saud, real-le son of the current Saudi king, and threw himself into the le of a career criminal.Over the years, he was often hauled before the courts, serving a number of jail terms for ious frauds worth tens of thousands of pounds.After being released, somehow he always managed to find new victims and keep up the charade.But when Gignac met suave Carl Marden Williamson in , a whole new world of possibilities opened up.The Brit was fabulously well connected, with “a Rolodex that was probably thousands of people”, according to we Denise.A former colleague told Vanity Fair magazine: “His line of bulls**t would change depending on the person he was talking to.“If you didn’t have a connection, he would be like, ‘Yeah, I know the guy. Let me go ahead and call them.’ It was frickin’ amazing.” Suddenly, Gignac had access to a huge global network of the rich and powerful.Together, they set up an investment company, Marden Williamson International LLC, and before long,  wealthy investors had transferred almost £.million into its account.Williamson also introduced the fraudster to a high-profile banker in London.She not only wired through £, of her own money, but also helped him to secure the investors who wired the millions to Marden Williamson International.An investment banker who was one of those to hand over cash, thinking it was for shares in Aramco — soon to be floated on the stockmarket at a value of £.trillion — later admitted: “I was fooled. It was a big, big, big scam.”Emboldened, the bogus Saudi began working on one of his most brazen schemes to date.In March last year, billionaire developer Jeffrey Soffer — then married to supermodel Elle Macpherson — was looking to sell the Fontainebleau Miami Beach hotel.To his surprise, the prince offered to buy it for £million more than what it was actually worth.Soffer, who was in the middle of finalising his orce from we of four years Elle, jumped at the prospect of the investment from someone he believed to be in “direct line” to the Saudi throne.But before the deal was agreed, the prince let it be known that he expected a certain level of respect.A source told Vanity Fair: “He indicated that one of the customs of his country was to exchange very lavish gts during the negotiation process.”So Soffer showered him with gts, including a £, Cartier bracelet and expensive artwork.The real estate mogul also flew Gignac to Aspen on his private plane for negotiations, where the prince stayed at the luxurious St Regis hotel and spent time at Soffer’s home.Then one night, while out for dinner with the Soffer family, Gignac made his fatal mistake.When choosing his starter, the man who had presented himself as a devout Muslim, ordered pork — asking for the prosciutto.The Soffer family instantly knew something was amiss and had their security team investigate the prince.They soon discovered what they called “key information that this person isn’t what he claims to be”.The Soffers tipped off police and Gignac was eventually arrested at JFK airport in New York last November when he presented a fake passport. He will go on trial in Miami on fraud and identity theft charges in January. A month after his arrest, agents interrogated his colleague Williamson, , for six hours at his home in North Carolina before charging him over the scam.When they left, his we Denise asked Williamsonhe knew the prince was a fraud. He said: “I didn’t know.” She believed him.That night Williamson, the father of two teenage boys, tried to kill himself and died two days later of his injuries.In an obituary, Denise called him a “mediocre domino player, occasional enthusiastic gardener, sore loser and intermittent fashionista”.She added: “My kids and I often cringed at what came out of his mouth, but he was also passionate, caring, had a generous nature and could make me fall down laughing.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: david cameron getting back politics
story: NewsopinionDavid Cameron getting back into politics is an absolutely brilliant ideaIts time to settle some scores with this entitled harbinger of chaosShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  NOV Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere are some reboots that should never have happened. Ghostbusters . Indiana Jones And The Annoying Son. The horrors that unfolded after Superman IV.Buttheres one movie that would benefit us all to see play out in Westminster, its True Lies : Mr Cameron Comes To Town. Otherwise known as the latest instalment in the Entitlement Chronicles.Theres nothing quite like over-weening self-belief for encouraging people to make arses of themselves, so we must thank Eton, Oxford and the Bullingdon Club for instilling so much of it in David William Donald Cameron, scion of William IV and une grande dame of believing he was born for the role.Today hes announced - well, lets be fair, he confided in a friend who put it on the front page of The Sun - he is bored s***less and would quite like to be made first a peer, and then Foreign Secretary. We have not been informed whether his preferred post is linked in any way to the skirt-lting, achievement-free high-jinks of his old mucker Boris Johnson in that position, because a spokesman refused to comment on the article. Perhaps that was because his boss, who was once such a bad PR man for Carlton TV he would answer the press office phone pretending to be the cleaner in order to evade questions, considered the press release to be all the info anyone needed.  David is dedicated to public service and has often said he wouldnt rule out a public role one day, domestically or internationally, said the friend, in an instruction to the nations current rulers to get him a cushy job in either the UN, NATO, or the international male modelling sector. After all, David Gandys going on paternity leave and those swimming trunks wont sell themselves.  He is only  and still a young man, added the friend, although it is unclear whether he was talking about the portly former PMs age, or his softening waist measurement. For since ordering a referendum that had the same effect on the nation as a dodgy takeaway, and leaving the resulting sloppy mess on the mat, Dishface has slunk off to enjoy the fruits of  fairly disastrous years in office. Those benefits have so far included a third home, not one but two pound, faux-shepherd huts, and a reported pound, advance for the memoirs he has conspicuously failed to write in the posh boy sheds, which some fool had installed a bed in.  He has been spotted lunching with Nick Clegg, dipping into the private gentlemens club Whites which he had abandoned when running for office, shooting game in Oxfordshire and making big money speeches. But his mates cant play tennis at lunchtime, Jeremy Clarkson is barely speaking to him and his former Number  is scooping up all the post-Parliamentary jobs and cash. So a permanent state of well-remunerated chillaxing is not making Cameron happy. Aww. Sadly a nice quiet job in Brussels is now off the cards after some bright spark called a vote to seepeople agreed with a multi-homed millionaire with a mouth like a cats bum. But there are a few jobs in public le that would suit all of us right down to the ground, and involve him fixing some of the problems he created. For example: . Libya  Making the man a peace envoy to the failed state riven by factional jihadis may be the only thing that will redeem Cameron to international historians. The man who once walked the streets of Tripoli accepting the jubilation of crowds freed from the oppression of Colonel Gaddafi would surely find it an easy task to persuade them to stop beheading, trafficking, murdering, raping and throwing desperate migrants into the Mediterranean in things that are called boats only by the criminally insane. If he found that too tricky, perhaps he could concentrate on collecting all the guns he released to the fundamentalist militia when he ordered RAF bombing raids on Gaddafis armouries, on the basis that Brits arming the rebels was not allowed, but Brits bombing a path to the weapons was a great wheeze. No  Well then perhaps he could try: . Food banks  At the start of Camerons reign in  , the Trussell Trust - largest food bank provider in the UK - handed out , food packs to people who relied on charity to eat. By the time he abdicated responsibility in   it was .million. And the Trussell Trust runs only about half of all food banks, so the real figure may be twice that. Even a cursory glance will inform you that David Cameron is not a man who has ever gone without pudding, so who better to be put in charge of ensuring pensioners, children, and hard-working but poorly-paid adults get fed  All right, they might find Weetabix, teabags and tins of beans are replaced with pheasant, dessert wine and foie gras, but whats a little gout matter when you can wobble your chins with joy.  . Hideous Gideon If that doesnt float your vengeance boat perhaps youd like to task him with releasing the nation from the cold, dead hands of George Osborne, the man who changed his name to sound more Prime Ministerial but thought being a lizard wouldnt matter. Im sure Gideons paying tax on all that lovely wonga hes making while planning how to chop up Theresa May and put her in his freezer, but perhaps David could confirm for us that none of it has found its way to Panama. . BORIS. F***ING BORIS Of the three Tory leaders who were stupid enough to give Boris Johnson a job, only Cameron failed to make him resign. The blond buffoon has trailed in his wake since school, knocking over ornaments, goosing the girls and generally annoying everyone. Its time Cameron took responsibility for the objectionable hound and had him neutered and enrolled in puppy school. . Oh yes, almost forgot. Total chaos  With the  Health and Social Care Act, Cameron cut a poundbillion-a-year management tier out of the NHS and then wondered why no-one was managing the NHS very well. And instead of properly funding social care, he took more money from the NHS to pay for it, while removing money from local authorities so they couldnt pay for it, with the net result that neither the NHS or social care had enough money. Then he cut every single part of the state. He removed investment from the economy. He sold the Post Office, Eurostar and Northern Rock for less than you could get at a boot sale and had the brass neck to say that the resulting economic despair was Labours fault. To top it all, he put the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland in a blender just to get rid of Nigel Farage, when all he actually needed to do was throw a few French waitresses at him. Were left with constitutional crisis, talk of barbed wire in Ballyconnell and Nigel has persisted like gristle stuck in a back molar. If Cameron really wants to make himself useful and perform a public service he could become chairman of the board at LBC, and fire the snivelling little toad.The list of Camerons cock-ups is long and glorious enough for anyone to spot that politics, and possibly cutlery, is beyond him. Theresa May has a drastic lack of achievement, but unlike her predecessor shes not got a failed state, starvation or laziness on her CV. There could be nothing more just, more popcorn-tastic, than rubbing Camerons nose in the crap he left us to deal with. If theres anyone who needs to learn about shit, its him.

title: theresa urged confirm ministers blocked
story: NewsTheresa May urged to confirmministers blocked MI probe into Brexit donor Arron BanksIt has been claimed security services were prevented from ­investigating Mr Banks in ShareByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  NOV NewsArron Banks with Nigel Farage: both have come under investigation in recent weeks "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May was yesterday urged to confirm whether or not ministers blocked an MI probe into Brexit donor Arron Banks. Labour’s Ben Bradshaw wrote to the PM a day after it was announced the National Crime Agency was investigating the source of poundmillion funding Mr Banks apparently pumped into the Leave campaign. It has been claimed security services were stopped from shyinvestigating Mr Banks in .  Mr Bradshaw said: “I have today written to the Prime Minister to askshe or any other minister or senior official has at any stage declined a request from any of our security, intelligence or law enforcement agencies to investigate Banks.” A No spokeswoman insisted: “We would never confirm or deny the detail of any conversation with shysecurity services on any topic.”  Tycoon Mr Banks is being probed for “suspected criminal offences” over campaign funding during the Brexit referendum. It came after the shyElectoral Commission said it had grounds to believe Mr Banks was not the true source of the cash. The watchdog also referred Leave.EU boss Elizabeth Bilney and parent campaign Better for the Country to the NCA. Mr Banks, a leading donor to UKIP when Nigel Farage was at the helm, denies any shywrongdoing. Meanwhile it was claimed in court yesterday that Brexiteers fined for campaign overspending were shyillegally hounded by the Electoral shyCommission. Vote Leave was fined pound, and activist Darren Grimes, , was ordered to pay pound, for breaching election laws. But they are appealing amid claims they were investigated by the commission a third time, after two probes found no wrongdoing. Timothy Straker QC, for Vote Leave, told a preliminary hearing the watchdog had “no power” to do so. The appeal will be heard in London. The commission will fight the claims.

title: brand new home wonky brickwork
story: NewsBrand new home with wonky brickwork becomes laughing stock of neighbourhoodDarren Harris sayshis marriage wasnt so strong the state of the house in Pembrokeshire, Wales, could have finished itShareCommentsByLaura Clements:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video brand-new-house-bad-neighbours-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brand new home with wonky brickwork and a sinking garden has become the laughing stock of its neighbourhood. Darren Harris forked out pound, for his four-bedroom home in Pembrokeshire, Wales, before it was built. But he says the condition of it has reduced his family to tears - and left his neighbours in stitches, Wales Online reports. Darren claims the property has a garden that is not level, a badly-fitted door and paving stones laid into the ground without cement.Astonishingly, he even says thathis marriage wasnt so strong, the state of the house could have finished it.  Darren says he has dealt with more than  defects since he got the keys for his new-build. Even his neighbours have been laughing at his expense, he says, pointing out the wonky brickwork at the side of the house. Persimmon, who built the house, say they are aware of the concerns and are working to reach a satisfactory conclusion. Mr Harris claims the problems started on day one. In June, I got the keys to my house and we drove down to the property, he said. The neighbours came over and asked meI had seen the brickwork on the back of the house.  They said to me We have been having a bit of a laugh and a giggle. When Mr Harris took a look, he claims he was confronted with wavy brickwork that wasnt straight and looked unsightly. The -year-old civil engineer was shocked. I know all about brickwork. Im a builder myself, and have run my own company for  years, he said. But the walls were just the start of his problems. As he entered his finished house for the first time, he tried to put the key in the door. But the door wouldnt budge. We couldnt get in, he said. I thought there must be a problem and went back to the site office. A Persimmon agent came back with me and in the end, he had to shoulder-barge the door to get it open.  It turned out the door frame had been fitted badly, he claimed.But the problems carried on. Mr Harris said: The problems are unbelieveable. He had bought the house at Martello Park, Pembroke before it was built. Together with his we, who is an area manager for Greggs, he has a number of buy-to-let properties in Pembrokeshire. He had planned to rent out the house once it had been completed. When we went to see the development initially, we looked round the show home, Mr Harris said. It looked like a nice spot, with views onto Pembroke Castle, so we put a deposit down in February . But ever since he got the keys, he claims the reality has been far from perfect. As well as the poor brickwork, we have found paving slabs have been laid straight onto rubble and earth, without any cement, he alleged.  The ground isnt level in the garden, the drain covers are sticking out of the ground, and the drains are positioned in the wrong place so the water runs straight past them. While I was there, I saw a worker laying some slabs and I could see he was doing it all wrong. Im a bricklayer by trade, so it was clear to me there were no footings under the paving. Even the guttering is all wrong, and not just on my property. None of the guttering reaches the end of the houses and water cascades down the sides when it rains. While I was mowing the lawn, I kicked my foot on the raised drain cover and actually broke my foot, causing me to take three weeks off work. Its caused my we and I no end of worry and stress. She has been in tears. If my marriage wasnt so strong this could have finished us.  Mr Harris, who lives in Sutton Coldfield in the Midlands, posted pictures of his house on Facebook. He says he is not usually the type of person to take to social media, but he was directed to a Facebook page for Persimmon home owners. He said: After I posted my story, I was contacted by Persimmon who said they would like to address my complaints. They sent a young guy round – he could only have been  years old. He spent half a day taking doors on and off, and making it worse. While Persimmon agreed to recty some of the issues, the problems persisted and Mr Harris took to fixing the problems himself. He drove the -mile round trip between the Midlands and Pembrokeshire throughout the summer, staying on a mattress in the back room of the Martello Park property.  Now, after spending thousands of his own money to fix the problems, Mr Harris has decided to take the national house builder to court. I have been on to head office. I have been brave enough to take them on and take them to the small claims court, he said. The rectication work they attempted was not acceptable. I have given them the opportunity to put it right. I have had to put off getting my tenants in, which has resulted in losses of pound,. We have been forced to get on with the retrospective work ourselves and it has cost us thousands. Thats the only way I could get the house finished and ready for our tenants. A spokesman for Persimmon Homes West Wales said: We are aware of Mr Harris’ concerns and we are working to reach a satisfactory conclusion. We have many happy customers across South Wales and we take customer service seriously.

story: NewsBritain to get far hotter and wetter as climate change begins to biteThe recent boiling summers and soaking winters will be the new normalShareCommentsByRuki SayidConsumer Editor:,  NOV NewsThe change in our climate will also affect our health "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritish weather is taking a tropical turn as the days get hotter and nights get stickier, according to experts. And the extra heat could mean bad news for our health.  The Met Office’s Dr Mark McCarthy said: “A particular concern are these tropical nights, when the body gets no respite from the heat.” “Tropical nights” – when it stays above C – have increased dramatically since the s. In the  years between  and , there were just eight sultry nights hotter than that. But in  years to , we’ve already had four C-plus nights.The Met Office predicts scorching sun and monsoon- style rainfall are likely tobecome more common in future. But a general background of climate change is not thought to be the only cause. Big cities seem to have their own effect. Data shows that, while the  heatwave was one of the most signicant for the UK, tropical nights only really stand out after . title: britains strictest school bans pupil
story: NewsBritains strictest school bans pupil from wearing remembrance poppy - because it was cm too bigGreat Yarmouth Charter Academy - which last month called in unorm police to measure girls skirt hems - told -year-old Courtney Dougal to take off the knitted tributeShareCommentsByJohn SiddleNeil Murphy:,  NOV NewsGreat Yarmouth Charter Academy has been branded the UKs strictest school "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain’s strictest school banned a pupil from wearing a remembrance poppy - because it was one centimetre too big. Great Yarmouth Charter Academy - which last month called in ‘unorm police’ to measure girls’ skirt hems - told -year-old Courtney Dougal to take off the knitted tribute. School bosses said the symbol was “too large” - despite being just cm bigger than the traditional paper poppy. Courtney, in Year  at the Norfolk high school, had worn the poppy with pride on Tuesday only to be told by principal Barry Smith to remove it. Her dad Raymond Dougal, , said he was “absolutely disgusted” by the school’s tough stance.  He said: “I am absolutely disgusted that they have made her take the poppy off. It is a little bit on the larger side but that is what makes it. “If it was huge and looked ridiculous I would not have sent her in it. “As it is it looks lovely. She is only little so that probably makes it look bigger than it is.” He added: “I said to Courtney to just go in and wear it but she didn’t dare.” Mr Dougal bought the poppy in his local pub The Sportsmans Arms in Great Yarmouth, with contributions going to the Royal British Legion. Landlord John Vale said the school “overstepped the mark” this time, branding the ban “disrespectful”. Charter Academy defended the move. A statement said: “Poppies are available in school and we encourage pupils and staff to wear them unfortunately in this case we felt that the large knitted poppy was not appropriate to wear in school.  “We are keen that pupils recognise and respect the sacrices made in war, and pupils are being encouraged to learn the poem In Flanders Field. “Many will be taking part in the town’s Remembrance Day service on November . “We are also refurbishing and relocating plaques commemorating former pupils of the Great Yarmouth Grammar School that served in battle, as a permanent reminder of that important heritage.” Last month, furious parents hit out after the school called in unorm police to measure theof girls’ skirts. Experts from a nearby unorm shop were consulted after pupils started turning up in short skirts. he academy has previously been criticised for its strict new rules on unorm and haircuts - banning one style called Meet Me at McDonald’s. The curly-on-top, short-at-the-sides look has been compared to the eighties New Romantic movement. It features shaved sides and a long tousled top with a floppy fringe.

title: first last british casualties wwi
story: NewsFirst and last British casualties of WWI separated by four years of fighting - and one patch of grassFew tales resound as profoundly as those of John and George, now buried just yards apartShareCommentsByTom Parry:,  NOV NewsTwo men of a dismounted patrol reconnoitring an a road near Mons, holding Lee Enfield Rles, "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBetween the death of Pte John Parr on August , , and Pte George Ellison on November , , more than eight million soldiers lost their lives. Mostly young men from the British Empire, Germany, France and Russia, these premature deaths were all equally awful for bereaved families. But today few stories resound as profoundly as those of John and George. At just , John, a golf caddy from Finchley, North London, had lied about his age to enlist. George, , was an experienced soldier from Leeds. In le they had little in common. But in death they will be forever remembered as the first and last British casualties of the First World War. Remarkably, their graves are only a few yards apart, separated by a thin stretch of perfectly manicured grass at the Saint-Symphorien war cemetery in Mons, Belgium. Although their deaths came more than four years apart, both men were killed on the edge of the same city.  Glyn Prysor of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission says: “The remarkable combination of ‘the first’ and ‘the last’ makes this cemetery particularly poignant. There are so many stories among the graves in this place.” Former miner George Ellison, can perhaps be considered the marginally more unlucky of the two men, even though he was much older than Pte Parr. Part of the original British Expeditionary Force of , shipped to Europe in August , he was involved in the initial battles around Mons, then Ypres, Armentiegraveres, Loos and Cambrai. Wounded at least once, he had recovered in time to join the advance as the over-stretched Germans began falling back from Belgium in the summer and autumn of . Having survived so much, he lost his le back in Mons again,  minutes before the bugle sounded the Armistice. He left behind a we, Hannah, and a two-year-old son James. When the actual ceasefire was signed in the forest of Compiegne five hours earlier, he would have been one of the few soldiers from the original BEF still alive. A century later, he is to be recognised with a plaque at Leeds City Station. Exactly what happened to John Parr has been shrouded in mystery ever since his mother went to the War Office in October  demanding news of her missing youngest son. Alice Parr was desperate but the military officials had nothing to offer. It is thought the young soldier, who enlisted as a -year-old in , and another recruit were sent out on bicycles to scout for the enemy.  The th Middlesex Regiment had arrived in Mons that day after marching from the French port of Boulogne over the previous week. Until that point, they had not seen a single German. Equally, German commanders were unaware the British Army was already in northern France, let alone Belgium. The idea was that John and his companion, a man called Beart, would report back to their CO in the village of Obourg, north of Mons. But on spotting the field grey unorms of the Germans directly ahead, John’s comrade reportedly turned around to pedal back to their battalion. The Germans opened fire and the younger solshyshydier was never seen again. British troops retreated and John’s body was presumably left behind. His death was not even officially reported until a year later. As late as January , the Infantry Records Office was writing to Alice to say her son was still with his battalion. These doubts have prompted several historians to cast doubt on the date on John’s headstone. But due to the chaos of those early war days, it is unlikely anyone will ever know for sure. A paving stone in the young soldier’s memory was unveiled outside his home in Finchley four years ago. There is also a plaque at North Middlesex Golf Club, where he was a caddy.  In an extraordinary quirk of fate, Mons is also the place where Allied forces fired their first and last shots of the conflict. A plaque in the adjoining village of Casteau marks where the BEF made its first official contact with the enemy at am on August ,  – the day after Pte Parr’s death. Cpl E. Thomas of the th Royal Irish Dragoon Guards is recorded as firing the first shot. These first contacts established what would become the Western Front. Back in , the generals believed the skirmishes would result in a quick war over in months. None of the top brass anticipated that both armies would eventually dig vast networks of trenches that would prevent signicant advances on either side for years. One of the saddest aspects of that final phase of the war is that George Ellison was far from alone – there were almost , casualties that last day. These men died even though their leaders knew war was about to end.  George does not even have the dubious distinction of being the last Allied soldier killed in the war. That was a Canadian, Pte George Price, , shot by a sniper at .am – two minutes before the ceasefire came into force. He, too, is buried in Saint-Symphorien, “one of the most beautul and unusual cemeteries on the Western Front,” according to Dr Prysor. He says “It looks completely dferent from other Commonwealth cemeteries because it was actually created by the Germans while the war was still being fought. “An old mining area was donated by a local landowner and planted with dark trees and shrubs to give the feeling of a woodland glade. “Both British and German soldiers were buried there and they were treated with equal dignity and respect.” And on this bleak autumn day, a century on from the Armistice, Saint-Symphorien remains a permanent reminder of the ultimate futility of “the war to end all wars”.

title: how meghan markle used 60000
story: NewsHow Meghan Markle used £, Down Under royal tour wardrobe to send subtle messages about her passionsThe Duchess of Sussexs carefully picked clothing symbolised a lot of her beliefs and causes she strongly supportsShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video duchess-sussex-didnt-simply-dress-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle used her royal tour wardrobe to send subtle messages about her passionate beliefs, it has been claimed. The mum-to-be impressed fashion-lovers with her incredible looks - covering everything from comfy casual to red carpet glam from high street names, as well as designer brands. And communication coach Robin Kermode believes the pregnant duchess, , used her strategically picked attire to signal her strongly held beliefs. In total, it is estimated Meghans Down Under tour wardrobe cost pound,. The items of clothing with signicant meanings behind them include her pumps created out of recycled plastic water bottles, and jeans made by female victims of human trafficking and sexual exploitation. With the world of the eyes upon her, some of Meghans outfits have unsurprisingly sold out as fans rush to snap them up. The jeans made by female victims of sexual exploitation  On several occasions during the overseas tour, Meghan opted to wear jeans from Outland - including the Harriet pair, pictured above. The Australian brand was founded by James Bartle after he saw first-hand how human traffickers prey on vulnerable young girls in order to service the sex industry. Determined to making a change, James learnt that once a girl has been rescued and supported through her recovery, a sustainable career path is vital for securing her future. He created the Denim Project, to enable those girls who demonstrated an interest in sewing to put their new skills to use. Outlands team of seamstresses offer positions to those at risk of falling into poverty, and has broadened its mission to set a standard for the treatment and remuneration of young female workers in the garment manufacturing industry. It also sources ethically and environmentally sound raw materials, from organic cotton pocket linings to recycled packaging. After the Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced their engagement, they asked people who wanted to mark the occasion to donate to charities they had picked instead of giving them wedding gts. One of these charities included the Myna Mahila Foundation, which empowers women in Mumbai’s urban slums, by providing them with a trusted network, where they are supported professionally and personally to help them grow as iniduals and businesswomen. Thus Meghans Outland jeans reflect her desire to help vulnerable women which she has spoken so openly about. The vegan leather trainers  Meghan went comfy and casual as she donned white Veja V trainers while on a boat trip in Sydney during the Invictus Games. The trainers got everyone talking as they are environmentally friendly, and made from raw materials sourced from organic farming and ecological agriculture. Some of the shoes also use recycled plastic bottles and many have soles made from wild Amazonian rubber. The French fashion brands founders, Seacutebastien Kopp and Franccedilois-Ghislain Morillion visited clothing and food factories in South America, Asia and Australia while running a nonprofit group — and were appalled by what they saw. So in , they founded Veja in France with the vision of making trainers using the most ecological materials and ethical suppliers they could find. Fashion fans were delighted when they saw Meghan wearing a pair and the duchess is keen on environmental and conservation causes. The recycled plastic bottle pumps  Meghan wore Rothys flats twice on tour, including during a beach clean-up in Melbourne. The pumps are made from recycled plastic water bottles that would otherwise have been destined for landfill - and have been dubbed the most politically correct shoes on the planet by Vogue. The insoles on all of Rothy’s shoes contain recycled foam the rubber soles are made without environmentally stressful black carbon. The yarn comes from plastic and even the packaging’s made from post-consumer recycled materials. Meghan supports charity Surfers Against Sewage, which is a national marine conservation and campaigning charity. It inspires, unites and empowers communities to take action to protect oceans, beaches, waves and wildle. Hugo Tagholm, chief executive of the charity said: Our work as a national marine conservation charity empowers tens of thousands of volunteers annually to protect beaches for everyone. We are currently focused on tackling plastic pollution and this support will help us move towards our vision of Plastic Free Coastlines.” So it is very fitting Meghan wore the pumps during the beach visit - signalling her passion to protecting the sea from plastic. The sustainable brand  The Duchess of Sussex wore a stunning custom-made silk wool cocktail dress in dark navy by Gabriela Hearst at Government House in Wellington. The sustainable luxury brand is based on a less is more approach. Gabriela is a notable feminist designer and political activist. She wanted to create a brand that reflects a slower pace and process: where things are made with care and detail, where tradition is more important than trend, where there is a purpose to every piece, according to her website. She takes into consideration where materials come from and who is making them. Meghan wore the dress to deliver a speech to honor the th anniversary of female suffrage. The empowering dress  Meghan looked sensational when she wore a beautul white Theia dress for dinner with the King and Queen of Tonga. The label is inspired by the Greek Goddess Theia, who had an incredible power to turn everything that she gazed on to light. The Theia dresses are designed to make women feel confident – similar to Meghan’s beliefs. The website explains about their collection: Inspired by the Greek Goddess Theia, this evening wear, bridal and day dress collection was created to bring out every womans inner goddess. One of the original Titans, Theia, who ruled during the Greek Golden Age, possessed the incredible power of light which radiated from her sparkling eyes. All that she gazed upon glittered, becoming luminous and radiant. She imbued gold and silver with their shine. She gave diamonds their fire and rubies and emeralds their sparkle. Her three children Helios the sun, Celene the moon, and Eos the dawn, all continue to bring light in to the world everyday. The woman who wears Theia will be filled with confidence knowing her dress fits wonderfully and looks beautul on her, thus naturally allowing her inner goddess to shine. title: paraplegic athlete drags himself through
story: NewsParaplegic athlete drags himself through Luton Airport on hands after staff left wheelchair on planeJustin Levene refused to be pushed through the airport using a high-backed wheelchairShareByNeil Murphy:,  NOV NewsJuston Leve was filmed dragging himself through Luton Airport "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShocking footage has emerged of a paraplegic man dragging himself through Luton Airport after staff left his wheelchair on a flight. Justin Levene, from north London, says he was left with no option but to crawl after his self-propelling wheelchair went missing. Staff had offered to push him through the airport using a high-backed wheelchair but Levene rejected this, stating that it robbed him of his independence. The video shows Levene dragging himself through the busy airport terminal as passengers walk by.  At one stage he even uses a luggage trolley to transport himself around the building. The incident happened in August  after Levene had arrived back in the UK following a flight from Croatia. Levene, who is a successful wheelchair athlete, was paralysed from the waist down after a operation to correct a herniated disc went wrong.  Levene is now suing Luton Airport after being left disappointed with the airports response, according to the BBC. He said: Ive worked very hard for a number of years to try and maintain all of my independence. And to be in one of the chairs they were offering would make me feel humiliated and degraded. They insisted in trying to strap me down in it. I wouldnt have been able to adjust myself, and would have been at risk of getting a pressure sore. Justins solicitors, Deighton Pierce Glynn, said the case isnt really about money, its about access to justice. Its time for Luton airport and other transport providers to be a bit more imaginative and enable disabled people to travel on equal terms with non-disabled passengers.  A Luton Airport statement said: On discovering that Mr Levene’s flight from Croatia had arrived without his wheelchair, our teams worked hard to find a solution, offering Mr Levene an assisted wheelchair as a temporary replacement. Mr Levene declined all offers of help. Whilst we apologiseMr Levene was dissatisfied with the service he received, we are satisfied that our agents and staff did all they could in dficult circumstances.

title: paul gambaccini receives five figure
story: NewsPaul Gambaccini receives five-figure payout from CPS over  sexual abuse allegationsThe BBC radio host, , was accused of molesting two young men during the s and early sShareByNeil Murphy:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsPaul Gambaccini has received a five-figure payout over  sexual abuse allegations "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPaul Gambaccini has received a five-figure payout over  sexual abuse allegations, it was reported last night. The BBC radio host was accused of molesting two young men during the s and early s. He spent a year on bail over the claims. But while announcing he was cleared, the Crown Prosecution Service wrongly suggested that his accusers had been underage.  It later suggested that there was ‘insufficient evidence’ to proceed with the case. story: NewsPensioner made hundreds of nuisance  calls for pasties and lts to bingoLena Taylor, , has continued to make abusive calls to the emergency services despite being convicted in JulyShareCommentsByKathryn Riddell:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsLena Taylor has been convicted three times of nuisance calls to the emergency services "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pensioner made hundreds of abusive  calls asking to be brought a pasty or to be taken to the bingo. Lena Taylor, , was convicted of making nuisance calls to the emergency services in July, when she received a two-year conditional discharge.But the elderly Taylor was back in the dock last month having made a further  calls to the emergency services between Jule  and August , reports Chronicle Live.But, seemingly undeterred, once again Taylor, of Wallsend, was back in court for a third time for a further nine phone calls. She walked free from North Tyneside Magistrates Court after pleading guilty to a malicious communications offence.  Lee Poppett, prosecuting, said: Mrs Taylor was abusive during the course of those telephone calls using foul and abusive language and not in fact reporting any emergency incident. The court heard that between July  and August , Taylor had been a great strain on resources and had an ambulance sent to her house on four occasions. Taylor was taken to hospital once but the other three times, she did not need hospital treatment. During one call on July , she rang saying Ive done my dinner, I need someone to take me to bingo to keep me calm. Stop f****** messing around with me. Im not going to sit in this house all day. A few days later on July  she demanded an ambulance and said: I want them here now. Bring me a cup of tea and a pasty. Hurry up Im starving. In another call later, she said: My pastys f****** fell on the floor you stupid c***s, get the ambulance out now. Mr Poppett added: Trust staff are reportedly being abused, insulted and sworn at and this is causing distress. There is concern about the impact its having on the staff.  But despite her repeated appearances before the court, it was revealed Taylor has continued to make abusive phone calls in the last few days. The court heard that Taylor has made  calls to the emergency services in the last three days. Mark Harrison, defending, said: This is a lady who has reached her th birthday without a conviction or caution against her name. Then in the course of this calender year she has found herself in a situation where her liberty could be at risk. Its a huge sadness that Mrs Taylor has found herself again appearing before the criminal courts. She has almost this compulsion to ring the emergency services. What she then says on the telephone to the emergency services is inexcusible.  She doesnt wake up in the morning wondering who to abuse next. The plan is to occupy her time, the plan is to alleviate her loneliness, the plan is to put her in touch with others who can provide help and support. Magistrates handed Taylor a  month community order and ordered her to pay pound court costs and an pound victim surcharge. Chairman of the bench, Wyn Clayton said: There are people all over the area waiting for ambulance for an emergency and whilst the crews are tied up coming out when it is not an emergency, those people can become victims of yours. You must take this on board. You are interfering with other people in the North Easts health care by making these calls. They must stop. The court heard that in future, emergency calls made by Taylor will be screened by her GP surgery first.

He is the second man to die by electric chair in Tennessee since . According to witnesses, -year-old Zagorski was askedhe had any last words and he replied “let’s rock” shortly before the execution was carried out. According to local media Zagorski , who shot and slit the throats of two men in  during a drug deal, also “smiled and grimaced” as he was being prepared to die.  His lawyer Kelley Helen said she smiled at him and tapped her heart and later told the Tennessean: “I told him, when I put my hand over my heart, that was me holding him in my heart.” Reporters who witnessed the scene said that the Extraction Team - the team that extract a prisoner from the holding cell to the chair - then put a sponge with saline solution on Zagorski’s head and secured it with two straps.
